title: UK consumers haven't been this gloomy for nearly 50 years
text:
Good evening

The bad news for the UK economy keeps on coming. Today's instalments showed consumer confidence dropping close to levels last seen in 1974, a sharp drop in retail sales, business activity cooling and the pound falling to its lowest level since 2020.

Research company GfK's consumer confidence index fell seven points to minus 38 in April, mirroring similar declines in surveys from Deloitte, KPMG and Bank of America and highlighting growing concerns over the soaring cost of living.

Retail sales data for March meanwhile showed volumes fell by a more than expected 1.4 per cent, the first sign in official figures of the impact high inflation is having on consumer spending, with worse data likely to follow as a result of April increases in energy bills and taxes. Annual inflation is currently running at a 30-year high of 7 per cent.

UK households are also investing less, according to AJ Bell, one of the country's biggest investment platforms.

Finally, new estimates from S&P Global for its purchasing managers' index — a more timely and forward-looking indicator than government data — show business activity suffering a “considerable loss of momentum”.  The “flash” reading for April was a lower than expected 57.6, where 50 marks the divide between activity growing and shrinking, compared with 60.9 the previous month, as increasing uncertainty around the war in Ukraine added to inflationary pressures facing business.

The retail and PMI data led economists to forecast a more aggressive programme of interest rate rises from the Bank of England, sparking a 1 per cent drop in the pound against the US dollar to $1.289. 

Chris Williamson, chief business economist at S&P Global, commented: “Orders received by manufacturers have almost stalled, driven by an increasing loss of exports, and growth of demand for services has slumped to among the weakest since the lockdowns of early 2021.”

Today's data follow new projections from the IMF on Wednesday that the UK would have the slowest growth in the G7 next year, undermining oft-repeated claims by prime minister Boris Johnson that the country was the fastest-growing G7 economy because of the success of its Covid vaccination programme and swift recovery from coronavirus.

Although a global pandemic followed by war are unique circumstances, many of the UK's economic problems stem rather from long-recognised causes such as a lack of business investment and the country's inability to solve the “productivity puzzle”, the FT editorial board argues.

“Many of the UK's other growth problems, whether its distance from the European single market or the country's restrictive planning laws, will take serious political capital to fix,” the FT says. But as long as the country's politicians are indifferent to its growth problems, this looks a forlorn hope, it concludes.

Latest news

  • Huggies maker Kimberly-Clark boosts outlook but warns of higher costs

  • UK embassy in Kyiv to reopen next week, Johnson says (BBC)

  • Indonesia to ban palm oil exports to shore up supply (Reuters)

For up-to-the-minute news updates, visit our live blog

Need to know: the economy

The Bundesbank warned that an embargo on Russian gas could cost the German economy €180bn, reduce GDP for 2022 by 5 per cent and trigger a deep recession. The estimate is far gloomier than academic economists had predicted. Our Big Read explores how the move would plunge German business into its “worst crisis since the second world war”.

The French presidential race concludes on Sunday as incumbent Emmanuel Macron attempts to fight off rightwing challenger Marine Le Pen. The FT will bring you the latest through Sunday night and into Monday morning. In the meantime you can browse our tracker for the final batches of opinion poll data.

Latest for the UK and Europe

The UK unveiled new sanctions against Russia including an increase in tariffs of 35 per cent on some Russian and Belarusian goods, including diamonds, and extending import bans to caviar and silver. Chancellor Rishi Sunak said the value of tariffs and goods bans now totalled more than £1bn.

Amid the UK economic gloom there was better news on the jobs market. Recruiter Hays said that wages for skilled workers were set to rise at the fastest rate since the collapse of Lehman Brothers.

The PMI reading for the eurozone showed a “two-speed economy” with services activity making up for a slowdown of progress in manufacturing, which was hit by rising costs and supply chain problems. The better than expected composite result of 55.8 was up from 54.9 in March.

Ukrainian prime minister Denys Shmyhal, called in the FT for Russian sanctions to be reinforced and updated, especially on energy and commodities, and for the country's allies to provide financial aid as well as heavy weapons. The IMF said Ukraine needed $15bn over the next three months. The US committed a further $500mn and G7 countries a further $24bn.

Global latest

US inflation expectations are at their highest level in decades, despite signals from the Federal Reserve that a more aggressive policy tightening was on the way. Fed governor Jay Powell signalled that interest rates could rise by half a percentage point at its May meeting. Markets editor Katie Martin warns that the fallout from the Fed's increasingly hawkish tilt will be unavoidably messy for investors.

China is launching an official private pension scheme to push more of the country's huge reserves of household savings into the financial market. The proportion of over 65s in China is forecast to increase more rapidly than other OECD countries, doubling from 10.6 per cent in 2017 to 26.3 per cent in 2050. The country's faltering economic outlook, alongside rising US interest rates, has hit the renminbi.

The World Health Organization urged Pfizer to be clearer about the pricing of its Paxlovid antiviral drug, voicing concerns that, as with Covid vaccines, “low and middle income countries will again be pushed to the end of the queue when it comes to accessing this treatment”. The FT editorial board said that the fight against Covid in the developing world had become a “parable of underachievement” but had also led to the neglect of other, far longer established killers.

Protests over the rising cost of living and against president Pedro Castillo are intensifying in Peru, including blocking of roads and railways, disrupting tourism and closing copper mines.

Need to know: business

Wall Street banks are forging ahead with expansion plans in Shanghai, even as the city's strict coronavirus lockdown disrupts current activities. “We're trying to build a 50-year business in China,” said a person familiar with plans from Goldman Sachs. “A disruption over several months isn't enough to shift the strategic thinking.”

Blackstone, the world's biggest alternative asset manager, said dealmaking would slow this year because of high inflation, rising interest rates and political uncertainty, even as it reported the best quarter in its 36-year history.

The EU is set to follow the Digital Markets Act with a new law that for the first time sets rules on how Big Tech should keep users safe online. West coast editor Richard Waters says the sector is struggling with mounting macroeconomic and geopolitical issues. The situation for tech and auto suppliers in Shanghai is becoming critical, reports our #techAsia newsletter.

Tesla chief Elon Musk said a factory shutdown in China and other supply chain problems would hit growth in the current quarter but stuck to bullish predictions for the full year. He said a new “robotaxi” that would hit the streets in 2024 would be a “massive driver of growth”.

Warner Media is shutting down CNN Plus just one month after launch as the streaming wars intensify. It did however manage to add 3mn HBO subscribers in the first quarter, in stark contrast to Netflix, which has moved from “growth darling” to “growth purgatory”.

AB InBev, the world's largest drinks group and maker of Budweiser, Stella Artois and Corona beer, said it would take a $1.1bn hit from the potential sale of its Russian joint venture to its Turkish partner, the first sign that Turkish companies might take advantage as US and European groups retreat. Carlsberg, the world's biggest brewer, has taken a $1.4bn hit from the sale of its Russian business.

Nestlé, the world's largest food company, is on a Swiss roll (thanks, Lex column) after managing to boost sales with price rises of more than five per cent in the first quarter, a tactic also employed by rival Procter & Gamble.

American Airlines, the US's largest carrier, signalled an end to pandemic losses and a return to profitability in the second quarter as passenger demand surged. Delta and United are welcoming back passengers previously barred for failing to wear a mask, after US authorities were stopped from insisting on mandatory face-covering.

One unintended consequence of the Ukraine crisis is the race by insurers to update the definition of war as businesses get hit by sanctions or retaliation. “Even climate change is easier to model than war-related activities,” says one industry executive. “The average underwriter can't know what a nation-state is capable of.”

Science round up

Pandemic management: The striking down by a judge of US rules making masks compulsory on public transport could make it harder to fight future pandemics, say experts.

Scientists say China's Covid death data is obscuring the true impact of the Omicron variant. Official stats show only two people have died since March despite tens of thousands of cases.

One of the casualties of the world's focus on Covid-19 has been research into cancer. Drops in cancer diagnosis — as screenings were delayed or patients feared seeking care — created a backlog of cases that also made it harder to recruit clinical trial participants.

Our Baby bust series explores how the pandemic has affected population growth and the consequences of changes in fertility, mortality and migration.

Vaccines: Novavax published positive initial data for the first Covid-19/flu combo vaccine. Bigger phase 2 trials begin later this year with a launch mooted by the end of 2023.

A Cambridge university spinout is searching for the next Covid jab in animal faeces. DIOSynVax uses the genomic sequences of coronaviruses in creatures to identify their “Achilles heel” which can then be targeted.

Pressure is increasing on Moderna and Pfizer to share their mRNA vaccine technology with developing countries. Companies editor Tom Braithwaite looks at what can be done to revive a market suffering from a massive oversupply.

The outbreak of infections in China has focused attention on the waning efficacy of the country's homegrown vaccines. The FT editorial board said Beijing should swallow its pride and approve foreign mRNA jabs.

Shares in Oxford BioMedica fell after it paused manufacturing of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine. Although Astra has supplied more than 2.6bn vaccine doses around the world, the mRNA jabs from BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna have dominated in richer countries because of a higher efficacy rate and concerns about a very rare side effect with the Oxford/Astra jab.

Science editor Clive Cookson says research into Covid vaccines has encouraged a new era of openness, including on the debate around animal testing.

You have been appointed Minister for Future Generations to make the decisions on climate change that squabbling nations have failed to for decades. Could you cut global emissions to net zero by 2050 while protecting nature and preserving livelihoods? Test your skills in our new interactive game.

Get the latest worldwide picture with our vaccine tracker

And finally.

What should we call you petrolheads in the age of the electric car? Here's something for you to drool over in the meantime in the shape of auto designers' plans for the supercars of tomorrow.
